newsitem.title: COTE D'IVOIRE: W.African central bank sells bills at fixed 4 pct.
newsitem.headline: W.African central bank sells bills at fixed 4 pct.

text.p: The Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO) said that it sold 23.9 billion CFA francs ($38.5 million) of 28-day bills at its tender on Monday at a fixed rate of 4.0 percent, the same as last week.

It introduced the fixed rate at its August 4 tender, and officials said then that it compared with the marginal rate of 4.70 percent at the previous tender on July 28. The average rate at that tender was 4.6410 percent.
Analysts said the lower, fixed rate was a signal to commerical banks to lower their base lending rates. The BCEAO has declined to comment.
The bank received offers for 23.9 billion CFA francs of bills from 12 operators this week and accepted them all.
It said its discount rate was unchanged at 6.25 percent.

The BCEAO is the central bank of the eight states that make up the West African part of the Franc Zone -- Benin, Burkina Faso, Guinea-Bissau, Ivory Coast, Mali, Niger, Senegal and Togo. ($ = 625 CFA francs)
